events.speaker: Ted Gibson
events.title: introduction

events.speaker: Ray Jackendoff
events.title: Language, Meaning, and Rational Thought
events.abstract: The process of thought is often experienced as “inner speech.”  However, on formal and empirical grounds, the aspect of speech (whether overt or covert) that contributes most to the form of experience is phonology (or possibly phonetics), which is ill equipped to serve as a vehicle for reasoning.  Rather, The referential and inferential functions of language are encoded in semantic/conceptual structure, which is, surprisingly, unconscious. As a consequence, the ideal of rational thought, of making reasoning totally explicit, is impossible to achieve, because the steps of reasoning are based on unconscious semantic structure. At the bottom of every train of “rational” thought lies a basis of unconscious “intuitive” judgment.  Nevertheless, inner speech aids thought  by providing a “handle” for atayention, making it possible to attend to relational and abstract aspects of thought, and thereby to process them with greater richness.

events.speaker: Nino Grillo
events.title: Composition-sensitive predictions: Incremental processing of (Long Distance) Experientials

events.speaker: Jacob Andreas
events.title: Knowledge and self-knowledge in language models
events.abstract: Current language models (LMs), trained on text alone, can converse knowledgeably and in depth about a wide range of topics. But these same LMs often generate confident-but-incorrect outputs, contradict themselves, and generally behave in ways that appear surprising and unnatural to human users. Increasingly, researchers attribute these failures not to surface-level statistical errors, but instead to mistakes and inconsistencies in LMs' "knowledge" or "beliefs" about the outside world. To what extent should we understand text generation in LMs as deriving from beliefs at all? How should this understanding influence the procedures we use to train them? This talk will survey some of the representational and behavioral evidence for (and against!) "belief-like" representations in LMs, and discuss training procedures that can attempt to shape them directly.

events.speaker: Julian Jara-Ettinger
events.title: Tracking Minds in Communication
events.abstract: Human communication is an intrinsically social activity that lets us share our thoughts through sound and movement. Accordingly, much work has argued that language must rely on Theory of Mind (ToM)—our ability to reason about other people’s minds. Yet, much work suggests that the interaction between ToM and language is surprisingly limited. In this talk I will argue that this is because popular ToM formalisms originate from studying non-linguistic social intelligence. By considering instead what kinds of social representations are necessary to make communication work, I will show that ToM extends beyond propositional mental states and includes micro-processes that permeate language use down to word-level semantics. These findings suggest that social cognition is not only an external system that can refine linguistic meaning, but also intrinsic to language itself.
